Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Computations of Time Dependent Highly Oscillatory Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many important systems in science, engineering, and industry are modeled by dynamical systems with solutions that are highly oscillatory relative to the overall time scale. Molecular dynamics computations for materials science and biology are of this form and so is simulation of neural processes. Such systems pose severe challenges to numerical simulations. In direct simulations each oscillation must be resolved over the full time interval, which is highly computationally costly. This research project aims to develop new computational methods that are well suited to simulation of such systems. An example of the infinite-dimensional systems that will be considered is high frequency wave propagation. One goal is improving the quality of seismic imaging. Earlier contributions have successfully handled cases with strong separation of large and small scales in the solutions by only applying microscale simulations locally. The current work aims at reducing this requirement by adaptively monitoring the solution and exploiting parallel-in-time computations.

This research will go one step further than the typical analytical or numerical averaging and homogenization approaches to deal with more challenging multiscale problems where there is no clear scale separation. The research will start to establish a new multiscale framework, which will support adaptive application of microscale models in small parts of the computational domain. The computational efficiency will result partially from parallelization in time. The theoretical goal is to establish a mathematical link between averaging theories to existing parallel-in-time computational frameworks and filtering techniques. The practical goal is to prepare the study of seismic wave propagation where the microscale model describes detailed diffraction and the effective macroscales are represented by geometrical optics type models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves research that tackles very challenging multiscale problems where the scale separation is less clear, the decomposition into slow and fast variables is not known, and where effective models of the given microscopic systems may fail to be valid in localized subregions of small sizes 

Intellectual Merits. The funded research goes beyong the scope of typical analytical or numerical averaging and homogenization approaches: the given microscopic models yield effective models which are valid only away from small and localized regions, and coupling of the effective and microscopic models are crucial and cannot be predicted a priori. This tighter multiscale coupling is achieved through a new multiscale framework which enables massive parallel-in-time computation. The funded research establish a mathematical link between a variety of averaging theories, existing parallel-in-time computational frameworks, and new effective numerical integrators and filtering techniques.

Broader Impacts. 

The funded research provides a systematic computational strategy for realistic computer simulation on future massively parallel computer architectures. The targeted areas are dynamical phenomena with strong variations in time. Typical processes that will benefit from this improved simulation capability are, for example, molecular dynamics, vibrating mechanical systems, dynamic biological phenomena and atmospheric flow. The novel computational methods and theoretical understanding will introduce new paradigms in the numerical solutions of challenging dynamical systems with a potential for many future realistic applications. Examples are fundamental biological and chemical phenomena based on first principles, computational seismology for more accurate imaging of the subsurface to meteorological and astrophysical modeling. The training of students in these fields is also very important, as they will shape the future of the development of multiscale modeling and high performance computing in academia and industry. This project has directly invovled 4 researchers at junior and mid career stages. It has also provided research training of f graduate students.
